title: Where will Dubai International Airport (DXB) rank among the busiest airports in the world by passenger number for 2020, according to the Airports Council International (ACI)?
preds:
Really difficult to find good news sources on this (all so clickbaity or US-centric).  This may be my worst performance. A few thoughts though:
 - Business travel and long haul should fall disproportionately relative to leisure and shorter trips
 - My gut feel is Dubai is dominant in both vulnerable categories so ought to see a sharper fall than other airports in the top ten
 - Chinese airports should rebound quicker which might skew the 2020 number? Shooting from the hip on all this.

All ships rise (and fall) with the tide. Why do we feel DXB is dropping disproportionately vs the rest of the world?[1][2]
The crowd is smart, and I followed the trend, but do we feel DXB is exceptional in terms of decline?...asking for a friend.
Do you feel like a Cassandra, @Wildwood2000? If we go down with this ship, just know it was a pleasure forecasting with you tonight... [3] [1] https://aci.aero/news/2020/10/08/acis-world-airport-traffic-report-brings-home-how-far-airport-traffic-has-fallen/
[2] https://www.arabianbusiness.com/transport/451086-passenger-traffic-at-dubai-international-airport-increasing-5-daily
[3] https://giphy.com/gifs/mrw-friends-night-MuyRCrNl5l3ysgnvQX

Montreal, 19 May 2020 – Airports Council International (ACI) World has today revealed its preliminary world airport traffic rankings covering passenger traffic, cargo volumes, and aircraft movements for 2019 combined with a glimpse of 2020 data which shows the dramatic impact of COVID-19 on airports in the first quarter. Passenger traffic at the world’s top 20 busiest airports grew by 1.7% in 2019. With more than 1.5 billion passengers passing through their terminals, this group of 20 represented 17% of global passenger traffic. The ongoing COVID-19 crisis, however, has brought airports around the world to a virtual standstill, resulting in airport traffic and revenue losses across all regions. ACI World now estimates a reduction of more than 4.6 billion passengers and more than US$97 billion in revenue for 2020. The combined 2019 and 2020 data shows the dramatic decline in air travel in the first quarter of 2020. In the top five, Beijing Airport notably experienced a -62.6% decline in passenger traffic but large decreases were also recorded across other top 20 airports in Asia-Pacific as the COVID-19 outbreak began to take hold in that region. https://aci.aero/news/2020/05/19/aci-reveals-top-20-airports-for-passenger-traffic-cargo-and-aircraft-movements/

Updating based on @kerryb comment: CAN = ~700 flights/day 
PVG = ~600 flights/day 
PEK = ~500 flights/day 
PKX = ~400 flights/day (still won't surpass DXB though this year) 
DXB = ~200 flights/day I am estimating that DXB lands in the #12 spot behind ATL, DFW, ORD, CAN, PVG, DEN, HND, PEK, LX, DEL and AMS It will be close though so hedging a touch in the 7 - 9 spot.

2019 top airports: 1. Atlanta (ATL) -- 110.5 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped 56.6% in the first half of 2020
2. Beijing (PEK) -- 100 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped 73.6% in the first half of 2020
3. Los Angeles (LAX) -- 88.1 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped 58.9% in the first half of 2020
4. Dubai (DXB) -- 86.4 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped by 56.4% in the first half of 2020
5. Tokyo (HND) -- 85.5 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped by 59.2% in the first half of 2020
6. Chicago (ORD) -- 84.6 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped by 57.6% in the first half of 2020
7. London (LHR) -- 80.9 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped by 60.2% in the first half of 2020
8. Shanghai (PVG) -- 76.2 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped by 68.1% in the first half of 2020
9. Paris (CDG) -- 76.2 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped by 61.4% in the first half of 2020
10. Dallas/Fort Worth (DFW) -- 75.1 million passengers in 2019; traffic dropped by 48.2% in the first half of 2020340 departing from LAX today ATL and PEK are clearly out of DXB reach. Will it take over LAX?
No: 179 departures from DXB today
340 from LAX What airports will go ahead of DXB? takes 3 to get to tier 7-9, 6 to 10+ Tokyo: ahead by a lot (hard to count but definitely much more than 200 departures)
ORD: ahead by a lot
LHR: ahead by a lot
PVG: 500-ish
CDG: 280-ish
DFW: waaaay ahead, too lazy to count. So with this, near certain to be 9th or 10th. In fact more likely to be 10th or lower.
Leaving 20% chance of being #7-#9 for a case of miscalculation/missing something
No much flying lately! No one is jumping at the opportunity.

CNN reported in early October that Dubai traffic had dropped a whopping 56.4% since the beginning of 2020. More unbelievable than that, however, was that they dropped less than 8/9 other airports in the top 10 with only Dallas (number 10) dropping less. While things are beginning to open again and hubs like LAX and ATL will almost definitely come out ahead, it's hard to see it dropping below number 6 given the difficulties every other hub has had. https://www.cnn.com/travel/article/worlds-busiest-airports-2019-coronavirus-impact/index.html
@cafebedouin your theory is sound, there is no way the whole ranking table will just shift lower by 60% in unison...

UAE flights resume after 6 months hiatus, from the aptly named BusiWeek media website (East African Business Week). https://www.busiweek.com/emirates-announces-resumption-of-passenger-flights-into-entebbe-airport/ I still think that this is too little too late, as airports in Europe and elsewhere have filled the vacuum created by the aggressive anti-Covid measures. Searches for flights from Asian cities to Europe now give me Istanbul and Zurich as top connections, instead of Dubai, not to mention direct flights from the fast-growing Chinese network of airports.
No change during the Covid-19 pandemic, but confirming Dubai's position as 4th. http://chartsbin.com/view/42520
Following @cafebedouin a bit to the very low end.

Crowd is wrong on this question.  LAX was 3rd, right in front of Dubai in passenger traffic in 2019.[1] For January through June, LAX had 17.6 million passengers.[2] Dubai? 5 million.[3] Want to guess what's happening in all those Chinese airports? Is anyone doing international travel through Dubai? Yet, they are going to stay 4th to 6th to 84% probability? I don't think so. 8)	Shanghai Pudong International Airport The websites below report as +/- 90% decline due to Covid-19 in passenger travel in the major airports.
Given the spikes in the coronavirus pandemic occurring in a variety of locations (Australia, Europe, U.S.) and the possibility of a second++ wave(s) of Covid-19, countries are locking down again. Globally, it is unlikely that air travel will improve and given the similar percentage downturns of the various airports and their importance as transport hubs, the proposal is that their positions of the league table will remain unchanged. https://airssist.com/10-busiest-airports-in-the-world-2020/  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/14/dubai-airports-passenger-numbers-plunged-20percent-in-the-first-quarter-as-coronavirus-crushed-travel.html  https://www.chicagobusiness.com/greg-hinz-politics/ohare-passenger-traffic-90  off 90% https://www.ajc.com/blog/airport/atlanta-hartsfield-jackson-sees-decline-passenger-traffic/fh43hozdSRh9peeRqMyVwN/  of 85% https://blueswandaily.com/beijing-capital-international-airport-pax-declines-89-in-mar-2020/ off 89% https://labusinessjournal.com/news/2020/jul/28/lax-passenger-traffic-down-87-percent-june/  off 87% https://centreforaviation.com/news/tokyo-haneda-airport-pax-declines-64-in-mar-2020-995453   off 64% https://www.expressandstar.com/news/uk-news/2020/07/13/heathrow-suffers-95-drop-in-passengers-in-june/  off 95%
Based on RRG and chiefthe's comments

For all of May, 44k passengers came through DXB, which would normally come through in a few hours [1]. The CEO is bullish on travel returning and numbers climbing, but while there is an increase in flights to even smaller destinations [2], and foreign flights are resuming [3], the other airports that are currently on the list are reporting higher numbers for May: ATL : 850k [4]
LAX: 580K [5] I was unable to find data quickly for the others in the top 6, but if ORD, at very least, is running at similar numbers as ATL and LAX, it is very unlikely for DXB to get ahead. Ranking it down quite a bit. [1] https://www.arabianindustry.com/supply-chain/united-arab-emirates/news/2020/jul/17/dubai-airports-ceo-anticpates-rapid-rebound-at-dxb-6409494/
[2] https://cyprus-mail.com/2020/07/16/first-resumed-emirates-flight-touches-down-in-larnaca/
[3] https://www.airport-technology.com/news/dubai-airport-resumes-scheduled-flights-by-foreign-carriers/
[4] http://www.atl.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/ATL-Traffic-Report-May-2020.pdf
[5] https://www.lawa.org/-/media/e0e3e2ce388c49e7b8961f97c7522d6d.pdf

As Covid-19 will fundamentally change the way we travel, at the very least for the remainder of the year, I see a shift towards regional hubs like Paris, Amsterdam and Frankfurt or large domestic hubs like Denver, Chicago, Guangzhou at the expense of "intraregional" hubs such as Dubai or Singapore.
Airports spread Covid-19 like wildfire around the globe. The busiest airports in the world during the pandemic will curse their country with an unstoppable amount of plague.

Dubai is #4 now, but the lead vs #10 is just 14%.
There are dozens of US and EU airports in the list. They will all be impacted less than Dubai. So low chance of 7-9 place and high chance of  10 or lower.
Lack of business and tourist travel - especially long haul flights
USA is in some serious trouble. Their airports in top 10 will probably not do well this year. Covid-19 and some kind of civil war that's starting.

All airports are going to be faced with social distancing and other measures that may limit traffic through them [1]. For the first quarter, the number of travelers were down by about 20% through Dubai [1]. The traffic for Dubai airport is heavily dependent (unsurprisingly) on flights by Emerates and flydubai, if looking only at destinations served [2]. Emerates started flying again to a selection of destinations as of May 21st [3]. Dubai was ranked 4th for Q1 for total passengers [4]. With these considerations in mind, all airports are likely to be facing similar restrictions to the movement of travelers through them. The critical question for Dubai, since it serves as a connector between the East and West hemispheres, is how full will those international flights be? Will there be a need to do as many long-haul trips as there were pre-COVID? HBR thinks there will be some decrease in globalization tendencies, but that they won't be breaking up completely [5].  With that in mind, I am thinking the Q1 numbers will most likely hold, with Dubai in 4th-ish place. If globalization breaks further, than it will drop further. There may be a small chance of it being one of the few connections open between the East and West, which may push its passenger totals up higher.  [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/14/dubai-airports-passenger-numbers-plunged-20percent-in-the-first-quarter-as-coronavirus-crushed-travel.html
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dubai_International_Airport#Airlines_and_destinations
[3] https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/travel/airlines-flights-resumed-coronavirus-travel-a4447196.html
[4] https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/life/story/Dubai_ranks_global_top_for_air_passenger_traffic_in_Q1_ACI-SNG_175082593/
[5] https://hbr.org/2020/05/will-covid-19-have-a-lasting-impact-on-globalization

According to ACI latest data, Dubai airport stands at fourth place for the Q1 2020. If the Haj pilgrimage is cancelled, there are chances of further drop. The chances of moving up depends upon the position of Beijing airport.
Adjusting as a response to the crowd...

-Strict measures they apply-->probably opening up later than most EU countries&US to not undo their efforts.
-Emirates in trouble, laying of employees, paying back customers, not flying,...
-Possibility that the opening of EU&US and their travell will force Dubai to open up as well and undo their efforts.
-Possibility that EU&US open up and there is no spike in cases and deaths(could be temporary, and spike again in winter), so no need to stay closed.
-Possibility that they open up with strict measures like quarantaining incoming passengers but don't think a lot of foreign passengers are up for that.
...

Interesting question.  Dubai has come up from around 13th in the world in 2010 to being 3rd in 2015/16/17/18. Top 5 (Passengers) in 2018
1. Atlanta Int (107 M)
2. Beijing Cap Int (100 M)
3. Dubai Int (89 M)
4. LA Int (87 M)
5. Tokyo Haneda (87 M) Top 5 - [International passenger traffic] in 2018
1. Dubai Int
2. London Heathrow
3. HK International
4. Amsterdam Schiphol
5. Seoul Incheon The above 2 tables should tell us that Dubai International is very dependent on International traffic and by being the hub of Emirates Airlines. TBF it is a great hub for air traffic connecting the East and the West. Also, 2019 data (preliminary) shows that Dubai had slipped to 5th (see how tight the nos are in the 3/4/5/6 ranks). Combined with the horrible things going on with international travel see things being tough for Dubai Int in 2020.  Baseline estimates (to be revised)
1st to 3rd:                5%   
4th to 6th:             25%
7th to 9th:             65%
10th or lower:         5%

Knee-jerk prediction, will investigate further:
Rationale being... expecting the rankings to be similar in structure; but lower in volume. Unless a hub/region becomes a C19 free utopia, how much can we expect the rankings to shuffle?  Those who *need* to travel will continue to do so as they did before. That said, a give or take of +/- 1 place will likely make this frustratingly/excitingly close.
